Will "OpenVSwitch DHCP" or "Openflow DHCP" be less ambiguous name then?

In the view of entire Neutron deployment, I may say it is indeed distributed, every compute nodes will serve the DHCP locally, no centralized stuff anymore. 'Openflow' and 'Openvswitch' are just the tools for us to achive the final goal: make DHCP distributed. Yes, it is just a naming method. We choose the name based on the result properties. We also have an famous example 'DVR', 'Distribtued virtual router', I don't think we can call it ``Iptables NAT Router`` or ``Policying Routing Router``. So, for this one, IMO, we can following the DVR's rule, because L3 and DHCP are basically in same service level for neutron now.
I guess server side changes should include network scheduling removal, DHCP agent notifications suppress, DHCP provisioning block removal, etc.

Will dnsmasq still be spawned to handle DNS?
No DHCP agent, so no dnsmasq (Line 98), and no DNS. But the Subnet DNS options will be still added to DHCP response related option.
Not only that, things like port-specific DHCP options will be ignored, right?  In the end this will more resemble what OVN does with support for a limited amount of options.

Port dns_domain, dns_name and extra_dhcp_opts, as well as Subnet dns_nameservers, host_routes, dns_nameservers and gateway_ip and so on, all these options will be added to the final DHCP response like dnsmasq do.

Not only OVN, but also controllers like dragonflow and opendaylight have similar DHCP responder for their clouds. IMO, Neutron has the all conditions to support this natively, and this will be more easily for existing clouds to upgrade.

What about something that looks for a major version greater than or equal to 15 instead of "octopus" here? Then it will work for future releases assuming the json schema doesn't change again.

if [[ $(ceph mon versions | awk '/version/{print $3}' | cut -d. -f1) -ge 15 ]]; then

Alternatively, removing jq and using '-f json-pretty' and awk will allow the same set of commands to work for all Ceph versions (no if statement required):

osd_stat=$(ceph osd stat -f json-pretty)
num_osd=$(awk '/"num_osds"/{print $2}' <<< "$osd_stat" | cut -d, -f1)
(Repeated for num_in_osds and num_up_osds)

I wanted to allow initializing the RBD connector even if it's unsupported, failing only when certain operations are requested. The reason is that the Nova Hyper-V driver is re-using the connectors, initializing them just once: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/22.0.0/nova/virt/hyperv/volumeops.py#L47-L49

We did that mostly because some of the Windows connectors are using various WMI operations during the initialization steps (e.g. validating iSCSI connectors), which can be rather time consuming, especially when attaching multiple volumes at once.

It's true that having to call "_ensure_rbd_available" all the time is rather inconvenient so I guess we may reconsider this approach and update the Hyper-V Nova driver to avoid caching os-brick connectors.

container-images/tcib/base/frr/frr.yaml.message:
This health check file is missing.

It is tricky to check liveness since FRR is comprised of a set of daemons (e.g. zebra, bgpd, staticd, bfdd, etc), so knowing which daemons are enabled and on which port, if any, they are listening to  is relevant.

I would suggest we make the assumption that the watchfrr daemon is always enabled (in fact, it is the only daemon enabled by default), and that it can respawn unresponsive daemons.

Watchfrr is a watchdog program to monitor status of FRR daemons and try to restart them if they are down or unresponsive.  It determines whether a daemon is up based on whether it can connect to the daemon's vty unix stream socket. It then repeatedly sends echo commands over that socket to determine whether the daemon is responsive.  If the daemon crashes, we will receive an EOF on the socket connection and know immediately that the daemon is down.
+1. It may not be the most reliable health check but it is a good start! ;)

Yeah I was going to look into healthcheck later on once we have a prototype container that works.

Should we then just create a healthcheck that monitors for watchfrr process running and assume it is doing what it can?

@Dan: it's dangerous to use image metadata for anything really important because it's both user visible and user mutable, unless we propose using property protections to restrict some fields by default in Glance.  We'd just have to make sure that those fields could be admin-only (that is, there would be no context in which they'd need to be read by an entity acting with project-scope (or domain-scope) credentials.

I agree that if we're going to modify the DB we need a bit more detail about whether this will modify any current tables or simply add a new one.

Well, we're using it for the import lock now, but by marking it as invisible and immutable, and namespaced. It would work the same way for this and I think be just fine, although I understand the desire not to pollute the metadata. Making the change formally in the DB is also fine (of course), but it's just so hard to do that in glance. Since this is really just a temporary scratch pad, it sucks to have to do all that work for it. In Nova, we have "system_metadata" which is not user-visible for things like this, where we stash things like an instance's original state during migration, and clear it later.

The nodes need to know what their externally-resolvable names are, so they can record them in the database. Does glance already have some notion of this? If not, we probably need to determine how we're going to grab that, and it would be good to record that here. Assuming nothing else currently exists, I would suggest that we have a new config option for each worker that defines the hostname by which the node is reachable. If unset, we use socket.gethostname(). We might also want to provide a config option for an URL template, so that if each worker is behind a proxy or in a container, we can ensure that the remote nodes use that (as is the case in devstack, by the way). Something like:

myhostname = some.other.hostname
myurl = https://%(hostname)s:123/path/to/
"for the"

I'm not sure what this means, can you expand? If we relay to the actual node that claimed to have staged the image, but the image isn't really staged there, won't that node return an error suitable for us to relay back to the client?

Or do you mean making sure that if a request to import comes in prior to a node having staged it, that we return some suitable error message, like we would today if we don't find it locally?
"requests'
Done

Can you explain why you think we should do this, instead of just using an extra_properties entry? AFAIK, the staging host information will generally need to live only for a very short period of time, between stage and import. After that, it's useless to store it. A new column is more work and potentially wasteful to store for each image (granted it's not a huge amount of data).

My implementation already stores it in a hidden and reserved os_glance_stage_host item. Is there a compelling reason to do it differently?
Added the extra_properties approach to the alternatives.

Consistency of use to start with. Using the extra_properties, we would need to lock down yet another key on the image properties and make sure it can be set only internally and make sure we clean it out once we don't need etc. With multistore having our staging store already configured as store we can use the existing store/locations tools to manage the staging data existence including deletion with minimal modifications. As of now we already have a need for rpc on delete where the deleting node does not have access to all the stores in the locations list, which would allow us to clean up the staging data on image deletion before import without needing to have extra special sauce for it. Now if the host is different column or part of the location uri is another thing I have no strong opinion about, but if it's on it's own column it makes finding the node where that data is bit easier. If we just pop the staging entry from the locations, we get rid of the data, entry tracking it and the staging host info all in one go.

> Consistency of use to start with. Using the extra_properties, we would need to lock down yet another key on the image properties and make sure it can be set only internally and make sure we clean it out once we don't need etc.

Brian suggested we just lock down os_glance_* in general, which I think is a good idea. We still have to pop out the data from the locations either way, so I'm not sure I see why it's harder to do that with extra_properties. We already have the synchronized image save in the import stuff after the work to fix the race, so it slots in there pretty nicely.

> As of now we already have a need for rpc on delete where the deleting node does not have access to all the stores in the locations list, which would allow us to clean up the staging data on image deletion before import without needing to have extra special sauce for it. Now if the host is different column or part of the location uri is another thing I have no strong opinion about, but if it's on it's own column it makes finding the node where that data is bit easier. If we just pop the staging entry from the locations, we get rid of the data, entry tracking it and the staging host info all in one go.

I'm not groking this, but I'm sure it's just something I'm missing. We just need to proxy delete as well as import, so that the staged host will do the delete and clean up its staging store, right? If that host is down, we can delete on that local worker instead of raising an error (as in the case of import). API workers need to clean up their staging residue on startup or periodically anyway, yeah?

Brian suggested "worker_self_reference_url" which, although slightly wordy, I think actually makes a lot of sense. To me, "cluster access" refers more to the "whole cluster" which is the opposite of what we want. I also think that bind_host isn't enough, for several reason:

- It doesn't work for native wsgi mode
- We need to include bind_port
- It won't work for cases where we have a TLS proxy in front of us
- It won't work for cases where we have a service-unifying proxy in front of us where we're reachable under a /image/... sub-path

All of the above apply to a default devstack deployment, and at least the TLS/proxy ones apply to our own RedHat-style deployments.

I really don't have strong opinion what the option is called. The "worker_self_reference_url" is pretty much as vague as the "cluster_access", both will need read of a help text to figure out why it's there. Any suggestions of concise name would be great.

"""that can be used instead by just omitting the new config option.""" I see none of your reasoning being why that statement couldn't be still true for any deployment that doesn't need to specifically set it for any of those reasons.

Because you think "worker" means the actual process we spawn instead of the collection of processes that we spawn for a given node? I guess I use them interchangeably. Cluster means all of the computers (to me) and if "worker" means the process what about "node"? I'd be fine with "node_self_reference_url".

I think my biggest problem with the "worker_self_reference_url" is overloading the worker part for another meaning. As the value does not refer to the worker (we have pool of workers in each service instance). On top of being mouthful for config option key.

> I really don't have strong opinion what the option is called. The "worker_self_reference_url" is pretty much as vague as the "cluster_access"

Well, it includes "url", which I think is important, and "worker" because it refers directly to a worker and not "the cluster". And "self_reference" because it's the "url by which the worker can refer to itself". Really, it has everything going for it :P

So I went off and looked at the location stuff after the previous discussion on this. I think I'm more convinced that this is the wrong approach. We'd effectively be putting a mostly-empty location in for an image, with a special link to say "but this worker has it in its staging repo, which we can't actually point at directly."

I would expect that to appear confusing to anything that can see that location without the normal stuff that goes with it, and potentially be confused about why an image has a weird not-complete location but also isn't active yet.

It's also a piece of data we'd store (or reserve space) forever in the DB, when it really only needs to live for the time between image create and completion of import. If there was any affinity to the actual store or location where it resides such that another worker with access to a shared store could hit it, that would be one thing, but it really doesn't, and AFAIK, the staging store really can't ever be something like a ceph repo. Even though the staging area is implemented as a store in code, the staging activity is more affined to the API node and thus tying the API node URL to the location-in-a-store concept does not seem to match up to me.

So I'm still not sure what this heavier approach gets us, or why the properties approach is for some reason problematic. I've already got the latter implemented and tested. Are you suggesting that we re-write that part of my implementation before landing, or could we maybe list the locations approach as the alternative, with the primary plan to go with the property approach? If there's something to be gained later by storing this in a location, then it would be trivial to do that later and just honor the property, if set, for a cycle or something.

I don't think we should do this, because we don't know the scheme, and we don't know if the remote side would be able to reach us on this bind_host:bind_port. If we're running in container, for example, this could be a 172.16.x.x address which is clearly not reachable from the outside.

This is why I fall back to public_endpoint, since that's a URL and worst cast, it just points to the same thing for every node. I'd rather fall back to just not doing anything if the specific url isn't set than trying to calculate it.
This is not unique to this spec, needs to be (and is being) done in parallel in a general way. Certainly not a reason not to do it I think.

driver-requirements.txt.message:
What kind of versioning guarantees is rbd-iscsi-client going to have?

I'm wondering how this plays out if we have to fix issues in rbd-iscsi-client for stable branches.
I plan on having this client owned by cinder.  So it's up to us.
The most recent version in pypi says it supports python 3.6 and 3.7; we need to support 3.8 in Victoria.  Maybe you can convince the maintainer to do a new release?  :)
I'll ask him....see if he can get it done :)

I've been thinking about this and for ongoing maintenance, I think it should be part of cinder, particularly given the wide range of people who work on the ceph driver.  There are two ways to go on this:

1) Some of the drivers that currently rely on a rest client have the client code in-tree in the same directory as the driver.  That would be simplest, but it does limit re-use.

2) If you think there's going to be interest in using your client for other projects, we can make it a project under the cinder umbrella (like cinderlib).  The downside is that it's more work (have to pick a release model, enhance the documentation, set up CI for it, etc.), but it's not an unreasonable amount of work if you anticipate independent use of the client.

Let me know what your thoughts are about this.

diskimage_builder/elements/pip-and-virtu.message: Why don't you use the 2.7 version? Seems like it would be a better match for installing on python2.
The right URL for this one should be https://bootstrap.pypa.io/2.7/get-pip.py . That one is for Python 3.4, which seems to work fine but that could change.

I suppose the alternative is to have a different version of this for platforms which provide no Python 2.7/3.5 (we'd perhaps still want it for, say, CentOS 7 or Ubuntu Bionic which provide Python 3.6 because they also still provide 2.7, right?).
This is going to install pip < 21.0 on all cases. Is this what we want?
so its ok. On executing get-pip.py its using also pip_args variable, which is set to "pip_args="-U --force-reinstall" so it should use the newest one if available for current setup, am I right?
I've tested this now and you are correct that it installs 20.3.4 by default. Adding a -U pip seems to fix this as well.

Doing more testing with the env vars and commands that dib runs it appears that you need '-U pip'. I think this is because get-pip.py for python3.5 is specifying pip<21 somewhere and if you specify 'pip' on the command line that uncapped request overrides the capped request.

Right. This solution was proposed in first commit to this patch - python2 version is using get-pip.py script from 2.7 branch when python3 is using master version. I like the solution that we use one script for install the pip, but it raise problem on getting newest version. 
So far, we can use -U as a next executed command to confirm that it is the newest one.

Are you sure that is the case? I is my recollection that get-pip.py does a pip install of pip from pypi. The bundled pip isn't just directly extracted. Pypi then has python-requires metadata for the pip package to select which version to install.

If they have hardcoded the version to install in get-pip.py that is disappointing. However, get-pip.py is also supposed to take pip install options so maybe you can run get-pip.py -U pip to work around this.

This would introduce a regression for current platforms because it will use only the old get-ip.py.

The correct approach is to use old get-pip.py only for EOL python versions and stick to
current one for normal ones.
I propose same in PS1,but it may not working at all with all distros. That's why Clark suggest to use old get-pip, then upgrade.
the script then goes on to use this pip to install the latest pip anyway...

Not really. For python3.5 it will install pip 20.4.3, when on update it upgrade to 21.0.
For python 2.7 works ok.
IMHO I really prefer to use the two different get-pip.py scripts and fix it in the future, when
some distro will fail at this point.

placement/tests/functional/gabbits/inven.message:
Full disclosure - we're missing the coverage for system-admin, system-reader, and project-reader that gmann wants included in these tests.

Each patch leading up to this one has it. Implementing coverage for those additional personas was giving me 409s, so I hadn't groked the placement API correctly or something.

I imagine you didn't use a different project and resource provider UUID for each test? If so, that's going to cause conflicts since everything in a single YAML file runs sequentially in the same environment. If we want to do this then I guess you either need to ensure you delete the resource provider before creating a new one (I don't think placement uses soft delete so you should be able to use the same UUID after the RP is deleted), or you'll need to use separate variables. For the latter, you can either configure these in the fixture (see the existing 'os.environ' configuration) or simply use hardcoded UUIDs (with a comment about why you're doing that, ideally). You could also split these into multiple YAML files but that seems rather tedious?
same nova did what you tried in 'Another approach', in nova unit tests I operated the all persona in single tests on same resource to avoid such 409. did that work?

The 409s were rather persistent. At that point I started trying to clean up everything in the test and recreate the RP from scratch, which still didn't work.

Another thing I'm doing is testing operations in batches (e.g., test that system-admin can create inventories, test that system-reader cannot create inventories, etc.) Another approach I was going to try was setting up the RP then exhaustively testing all operations for a single persona before moving on to the next persona. 

Worst case we can break things into separate files for each persona. But, I do agree that seems tedious.

I don't think we'd really want this to be returned as a "volume_type" obj with two fields in it -- this means a lot more work on the client side of checking the microversion and changing how this field is parsed, and is more of a change between microversions than is really necessary.

I think it would work better to just return:
    volume_type: 5fed9d7c-401d...
    volume_type_name:  lvmdriver-1

as separate fields.

You do know that the response already contains object elements such as "links", "attachments", and "metadata".

I personally prefer to handle objects and I do not see the much work on the client side to do that, but if the only way to get this merged is to use this flat proposal of yours. I can live with it.

Do you want to get feedback from other people on this matter (e.g. Sean and Rajat) before I change it?
I was wondering about including this extra stuff, but it's because your test sets the mv to 3.63, and as a result, the response will include all the stuff from lower microversions too.
nit: There was no need to change the volume_type, since the __DEFAULT__ type also has an UUID, and I think it has value to see in the samples the __DEFAULT__ type.

That means that there's a need for another independent patch that fixes this, and then this patch would be chained with that one so it is self sufficient.

But I won't downvote for it since there's a low core review bandwidth and we should try to move this patch along.

I'm wondering if we should also be updating this to say:

  role:admin and system_scope:all

Instead of just:

  role:admin

Technically - line 60 adds scope checking in the event the API is called with a non-system-scoped token, but that's only true if enforce_scope=True in placement.conf, which deployers probably can't flip until all services in their deployment are on the same page with policy.

Currently, this works because only admin (project admin specifically) can call this API, which is the equivalent to what we're calling system adminstrators. While enforce_scope is set to False, we might need to consider adding protection with `system_scope:all` in the actual check string so that we don't accidentally open up system administrator APIs to project administrators.

Not sure why I didn't catch this in the first go.

Fixed.

Newb question, but why don't you have to specify the scope types for the deprecated rule? Does it inherit them from its replacement? Crucially, would this allow a project-scoped (rather than system-scoped) admin to use this APIs even if '[oslo_policy] enforce_new_defaults = False' and '[oslo_policy] enforce_scope = False' were set? Maybe it doesn't matter here because there's no project information passed through when checking the policy, but I'm curious.

A lot of the admin API rule checks only really checked for the existence of the admin role somewhere in the token roles. Those checks existed prior to the scope work we did in keystone and the various libraries.

Scope types weren't include in the deprecated rule since they weren't really applicable to the original check strings across OpenStack. However, I can see how that would potentially be useful moving forward.

Stephen, 

Using `system_scope:all` is a special designation for a system-scoped token that maps to the entire deployment system (e.g., 'all' is special in this sense). In the future, keystone might expose the service catalog as authorization targets, allowing us to do something like this:

  $ openstack role add --user stephenfin --user-domain Default --system compute admin  # these assignments aren't supported today
  $ openstack role add --user stephenfin --user-domain Default --system all reader # these assignments are supported today
  $ openstack role add --user gmann --user-domain Default --system identity admin  # these assignments aren't supported today


Which gives us much more flexibility for breaking up access to all system-level APIs. If, or when, that happens, we could update policy checks to include:

  (role:reader and system_scope:placement)

Which would allow you to manage things in placement, but Ghanshyam wouldn't be able to access anything in placement since his system tokens are specific to the keystone service. Conversely, you could list all resources in keystone, but you wouldn't be able to create new domains, groups, projects, users, etc...

Putting roles in a hierarchy and breaking the system into smaller authorization targets follows a NIST RBAC model that allows OpenStack to implement separation of duty requirements.

This is a long-winded answer, but you're absolutely on the right track looking at system_scope:placement.
and that way we can avoid the rule deprecation for admin policy. basically placement need to add read-only rules only.

placement/policies/resource_provider.py.message:
As an unrelated aside, I'm not sure why these parameters were implemented here initially as opposed to as parameters of the 'DeprecatedRule' object. In oslo.config land, 'deprecated_group' is independent of 'deprecated_reason'/'deprecated_since', with the former being used to indicate that the current opt was previously in another group, while the latter are used to actually deprecated the opt (plus any aliases left in the other group). That's not what we seem to be doing here.

Later: Oh, wait, I don't think this was ever intended to work this way. From the docs [1]:

  :param deprecated_reason: indicates why this policy is planned for removal
                            in a future release. Silently ignored if
                            deprecated_for_removal is False.
  :param deprecated_since: indicates which release this policy was deprecated
                           in. Accepts any string, though valid version
                           strings are encouraged. Silently ignored if
                           deprecated_for_removal is False.

However, later on I see docs that use it like we've done here [2] and I think this is what we did in nova too. Clearly there's a gap here and 'DeprecatedRule' should have its own 'deprecated_reason' and 'deprecated_since' options.

I guess we can do this for now, but it'd be good to add a note explaining why this is happening. As this is implemented, it really looks like the new options are deprecated as well as the alias /o\

I've read the gabbi documentation and it suggests keeping test files as small as possible [0].

Should this be broken into a smaller files?

[0] https://gabbi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq.html?highlight=vars#how-many-tests-should-be-put-in-one-yaml-file

The original idea was that each file should represent the arc of a series of requests to complete an action. In part simply because "small is good", but also because the tests run as a sequence and are not parallelized when they are all in the same file.

So, if there isn't a sequence here it might make sense to separate them out.

However, in placement we generally ended up with yaml files per-topic, not per-arc and this one is by no means excessive so I'd say it's fine to keep as is.

I think I've confused you by giving 'check_str' as the example above. It's not the 'RuleDefault.check_str' value that changes, it's the 'RuleDefault.check' value, which is a parsed version of the 'check_str' [1]. That modification happens at [2], which I linked in the commit message below, if there's a 'deprecated_rule' attribute, the 'check_str' values don't match, and '[oslo_policy] enforce_new_defaults' is set to False. Basically it ORs together the deprecated rule's 'check_str' value. The fact that it doesn't update 'check_str' after is a mistake and something I agree we should fix, however, there's definitely a bug here that we need to fix. If you want to debug this yourself, look at the bug when I demonstrated my wonderful printf-debugging skills 😄

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/3.6.0/oslo_policy/policy.py#L1177
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/3.6.0/oslo_policy/policy.py#L762-L764

Yeah if you modify the check_str then it is issue. I understand the concept of modifying on object. But in oslo.policy nothing modify the check_str on registered default rules. oslo polocy only modify the self.check[1] which is different attribute prepared locally and different[2] from what service defined like check_str or scope etc. So registered rule check_str does not get modified in original object at any time.

I ran few of the scenario and did not find that registered original rule check_str is modified with policy run, it stay same what service define. did you get tests conflict due to change in rule enforcement because of rule original check_str is changed by oslo polocy?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/e103baa002e54303b08630c436dfc7b0b8a013de/oslo_policy/policy.py#L762 
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/e103baa002e54303b08630c436dfc7b0b8a013de/oslo_policy/policy.py#L1176-L1177

Yup. Consider this example:

  >>> class Enforcer:
  ...     def __init__(self, rules):
  ...             self.rules = rules
  ...     def reset(self):
  ...             self.rules = None
  ...     def set_rules(self, rules):
  ...             self.rules = rules
  ... 
  >>> class Rule:
  ...     def __init__(self, check_str):
  ...             self.check_str = check_str
  ... 
  >>> rules = [Rule('foo'), Rule('bar')]
  >>> enforcer = Enforcer(rules)
  >>> enforcer.rules
  [<__main__.Rule object at 0x7fc08099eca0>, <__main__.Rule object at 0x7fc08099ed30>]
  >>> [r.check_str for r in enforcer.rules]
  ['foo', 'bar']
  >>> enforcer.rules[0].check_str = 'baz'
  >>> [r.check_str for r in enforcer.rules]
  ['baz', 'bar']
  >>> enforcer.reset()
  >>> enforcer.rules
  >>> enforcer.set_rules(rules)
  >>> [r.check_str for r in enforcer.rules]
  ['baz', 'bar']

The 'Rule' objects are persistent, which means if we modify them inside the enforcer then those changes are persistent.

I suppose this patch is to address the sparse issue, no? They are different problems I think. The concurrency problem exists whether with this fix or not, in fact this patch will increase the chance you worried about, if parallel downloads happens.

You are serious, it's not likely to have such an image :)

the available disk space is up to the /var/lib/ironic (or whatever mount point/partitioning deployers set up), the cache cleanup is just a promise to reduce cache size to configured limit, the real restriction still lies in the available disk space.

anyway, I think this patch has done it's job \o/

No idea on the concurrency problem, the cache is cleaned up for the the space before conversion, I guess it could be happening that some of them will fail as they are parallely consuming spaces, it's an edge case though.

I don't come up with a solution without space management alike thing, reserving spaces required before consuming is one of possible ways I guess.

That's what I am trying to understand - is there a use-case when multiple images being unpacked simultaneously. Seems like this might happen when `parallel_image_downloads` option is in force.

That kind of undermines the purpose of this patch - even if we did our guesswork on unpacked image size, it still can fail on space shortage in case of parallel deployments.

Given that ironic is targeting hundreds/thousands of nodes under a single conductor, simultaneous deployment feels quite likely. The only relaxing factor I can think of is that many nodes are likely to deploy the same image....

> > in fact this patch will increase the chance you worried about, if
 > parallel downloads happens.
 > 
 > Well, this patch effectively reduces the upfront free space
 > requirement (full raw image size vs compressed size times a
 > constant).
 > 
 > Therefore it seems that even in case of parallel downloads the
 > chance of unjustified failure (due to unmet upfront space
 > requirement) should be lower, no?
 > 

As I understand it, this patch is trying to reduce space claims when sparse images are used, the claimed size is likely in the range of disk_size and virtual_size (affected by factor, I think the intention is between the two).

As a higher space claims will free more cache space for subsequent conversion, so in the case of parallel downloads, claiming virtual_size will have a lower chance than the size between disk_size and virtual_size, probably the room vacated by ironic would hold much more guests.

> I suppose this patch is to address the sparse issue, no?

Yes, exactly!

> in fact this patch will increase the chance you worried about, if parallel downloads happens.

Well, this patch effectively reduces the upfront free space requirement (full raw image size vs compressed size times a constant).

Therefore it seems that even in case of parallel downloads the chance of unjustified failure (due to unmet upfront space requirement) should be lower, no?

However the whole space requirement business seems shaky to me given the presence of parallel downloads - we compare free space against the size of the image to be unpacked, but we completely ignore the fact that we may unpack multiple images potentially exceeding free space.

But you are right - if we want to address it, that should be the topic of another patch.

> will free more cache space for subsequent conversion

Assuming there is enough space that can be freed and used for conversion. I am worrying of the case when we have large images (say, 500GB uncompressed) being requested at the same time...

I'm confused here. Are we talking about running nginx in each container where a service needs it? Or are we talking about making containers with only nginx in them that proxy into uwsgi in other containers?

Well - either really. Its about adding flexibility to decide where your nginx runs - By default I'm going to suggest specific containers with nginx in them - e.g. 1 on each infra host, with each service utilizing the same 3 nginx hosts.

However you could just as easily point the nginx_nova_placement role (for example) to deploy on the same container as nova_placement service.

The key (to me) is that the deployer can control where the service is deployed, similar to how other services are deployed, and could therefore scale out nginx separately, and if needed - specifically per service.

I'm mostly a layman on this topic. I understand the general reasoning behind the eventlet -> uWSGI change, but rather than looking at whether "uwsgi standalone" is necessary and/or useful, I'm accepting that uWSGI standalone is the starting point change as this spec lays it out, but I don't understand quite yet what uWSGI+nginx adds for us that makes it worth all the additional complexity.

After reading the spec I wonder why we aren't just specing out the eventlet -> uWSGI change. Does nginx need to be part of this spec? Does nginx need to be part of OSA at all? If so, why?
I'd agree with this hierarchical grouping

I think this paragraph deserves a rephrasing, it looks confusing to me.

For me the best way to control where you want to target your role is the playbook.

I'd rather not put nginx as a role meta requirement, because this means it's always gonna be deployed everywhere. I'd rather call it at the same place we do our playbooks. Keep the same flexibility, but not forces a dependency.

IMO a dependency is a strong dependency on what needs to run in order for your role to work. Each role can definitely not need nginx, because uswgi can be "working on its own".
Specific nginx containers on infra hosts would be another child group of 'nginx_all'?

So we can include the role tasks to setup the vhosts which should work ok - but it would still need to be targeted against a host (and in this case an nginx_group host)

We may run into issues if it's not a dependency/include because we need to utilise the nginx role handlers for restarts/managing within the role. We can include the role itself using the "include_role" module, this may not be sufficient to allow access to the handlers - would need to look into that.

IMO it is a strong dependency until we add the ability to deploy using "not nginx" which at the moment we don't. If we want nginx to be optional then we need a tested/working "uwsgi standalone" which im not sure is necessary and/or useful.

for me ansible_host should always be the remote destination IP: it's set in many places in our playbooks/roles to be considered as an IP. In ssh connection case, it is an IP.
I would like to keep the same meaning ansible_host==IP, should we decide to change in the future.

A purpose of our connection plugin was to add the extra ability to directly connect to the container without the need for this IP.

Maybe what we should do instead, is to remove ansible_host for those hosts/groups vars, and only define the two variables necessary to connect: container_name= and physical_host=

If we want to run a full deploy, maybe:
1) this shouldn't be tested here in the same job as our current functional testing (but in a scenario like the experimental one)
2) we should work on removing this dependence on ansible_host everywhere

Just my 2cents.

Also agree regarding possibly breaking out the connection tests into some separate jobs with individual inventories targeted to different scenarios since there are so many permutations of ansible inventory configurations we need to cover.
And yes this line is just here as I'm still debugging the various ways to break the plugin right now. I agree 100%, it should not exist in this group file if/when this patch merges.

That's a fine assumption for OSA, because OSA's dynamic inventory will populate the container ansible_host with the management IP.

That's not a fine assumption for a connection plugin that doesn't use ansible_host to connect to the containers. The container IP may not be known, and the plugin should not expect ansible_host to be set at all when dealing with an inventory host that is a container.

In ansible when you have an inventory item that does not contain an ansible_host, the ansible_host gets set to inventory_hostname.

In that situation, the connection plugin is currently broken. It will no longer recognize the host as a container: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins/blob/a3add1e7b07236448b251d38709430ae40dca1fe/connection/ssh.py#L418

You're thinking of the what/why in terms of the amendments you make. Those are unnecessary. In gerrit everything is a single commit, so the commit message must always reflect the final commit message which describes the what/why for what you intend to have merged.

oslo_cache/_opts.py.message:
I wondering if it should set to `True` instead, to keep the original behavior as it was before these changes and avoid side effects on user side especially with users who are not aware of these changes and not impacted by this bug or also users who expects that `flush` will happen.

I personally prefer sitting me on the other side of the table, I mean not `flush` only when this really requirered (like in your case).

I know that the goal of these changes is to make this behavior optional, but it could be seen as the opposite too.

In your case you could fix your issue by passing false to this option in your config, and other users will not see difference on their side.

it would be interesting to debate a bit about this point. I want grab more feedbacks from other core developers especially from Moises.

In one hand we fix a bug and on the other hand we reintroduce an old bug, so I think it's worth to speak a bit about it.

Thoughts?

In the case we decide to fix the root cause then I think we could either turn the default option value to True or revert these changes and remove config, but not convinced that back and forth with options are a good idea in a user point of view, I mean it could disturb users and operators to add and remove options every 5 minutes and so it could be preferable to keep the option even if python-memcached will be fixed.

Anyway in all the case we risk to face an issue (the stale data or the rally), and I think you are right and I think that we should give priority to the race as this is a scenario more easily to observe and as the flush on reconnect is mostly dedicated to keystone first. So in other words I agree with you and I'm OK to continue with the current behavior.

Also it could be intesting to dive deeper in python-memcached to seen the root cause of this issue, I mean oslo.cache is based on python-memcached and connections are managed by him, so in this case I think the root cause is hidden there.

I think this patch is a good workaround by waiting to find more clues about the root cause.

Also I need to continue to work on the migration from python-memcached to pymemcache [1], which could help us to solve this issue, as pymemcache handle connections in a different way.

Thanks for your feedback and your opinion on this topic :)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711220/

pymemcache doesn't need to flush on reconnect and so the both bugs doesn't exist with pymemcache.

 > 
 > Thanks for your feedback and your opinion on this topic :)
 > 
 > [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711220/

I don't agree : 

1. Switch default value to True - original behaviour was to have memcache_pool_connection_get_timeout turned off (turned on only in master branch) always
2. Avoid side effects on user side - Well, if we switch default value from False to True directly in oslo.cache, users will have issues
3. Flush_on_reconnect is optional arg, so we should provide way to change this option, by default it is False also in python-memcached

4. If we consider that this option can make openstack unresponsive because dead caches (very easily - just try to run rally against OS , and you will see), I think this option should be False be default.

I think we need to expose this with a set_defaults API for this library that allows Keystone to override the default. See https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy/src/commit/a626ad12fe5a3abd49d70e3e5b95589d279ab578/oslo_policy/opts.py#L121 for example.

Then we'll need a followup for Keystone to opt in to this behavior by default.
I would like to see some discussion of the potential security implications of turning this off.

nit: I suggest removing this since it's ambiguous.
Are network connections directly related to flush events? This sentence implies flushing the cache causes network disconnects. Is that the case or am I misreading this?

Well, simply said yes.

Imagine that you have huge requests to cache ( in our deployment it is kubernetes who do it)

Well, yes 

In real when memcached's client's connection is broken , whatewer reason it is ( typically some network issue, restart, etc..) client will connect again to memcached server, but will flush memcached on reconnect.

Let's imagine that we have two memcached servers.
Imagine that one server was unresponsive.

After unresponsive node appear, memcached node is trying to cache data, but clients are still flushing cache because they have flush_on_reconnect turned on, which causing memcached to be extremly overkilled, connections are growing until memcache is dead, so it is unresposive again.

When it is unresponsive, clients are connecting to another memcached which can be unresponsive in short time, because all requests to cache is now served only from one memcached server.

When first memcached node start to be responsive again, process is repeated, because clients are connecting to it and flushes again, because it was unresponsive.

We met this bug when upgrading openstack via kolla-ansible.
Problem appeared when big traffic was going to memcache.

In Closes-Bug report i simulated flushs with while script to flush cashes, check it , maybe it will be more descriptive for you.

Reverted oslo.cache fixed issue immediately.

Hope that it is more clear.


This problem is visible only under big load, but it's definitively issue

I think that this flag doesn't mitigate the problem entirely. If I understand it correctly the original attack vector is:
- Issue token
- Somehow stop memcached server that stores this token
- Revoke token
- Start memcached server again
- Token is valid again and can be misused
But even with flush_on_reconnect similar issue is still possible:
- Issue token
- Somehow stop memcached server that stores this token
- Wait before someone is use this token again so it is again pushed to the other memcached (token is still valid)
- Start memcached server
- Revoke token
- Stop the original memcached server again
- Since the other memcache is still holding the old token it is valid again despite the fact that you have flushed the data on the original memcache (that was stopped and started and stopped again)

So it's actually doesn't improve security that much. And add a ton of problem with performance.

Let me see if I understand this correctly.

The root cause is a network connectivity problem, but it's exacerbated because the memecached cluster isn't big enough, correct?

Did disabling flush_on_reconnect completely fix the issue or did you eventually scale up your memcached deployment? Without scaling up, won't future network partition events cause the same issue?

Morgan eluded to this in his comment, but my concern about keeping stale data around is primarily due to security. For example, say I authenticate for a token and it's stored in memcached-1. Sometime between when my token is cached and its expiration, memcache-1 becomes unreachable, at which time my user is disabled, revoking my token. Now, memcached-1 rejoined the cluster, my invalid token is technically cached and still valid according to keystone it if fetches the token from memcache-1, right?
